animalOfTheDay.name: seahorse
facts: They are poor swimmers, relying on camouflage and slow movements to avoid predators.
Seahorses are the only fish where males become pregnant and give birth.
Seahorses lack stomachs and must eat constantly to survive.
They have prehensile tails to grip seagrass and corals, avoiding strong currents.

calendar.name: sardine
facts: They are an important food source for many marine predators, including whales and dolphins.
Sardines get their name from the Italian island of Sardinia where they were once abundant.
Sardines swim in massive schools that can contain millions of fish.
They are rich in omega-3 fatty acids and are an important commercial fish.

calendar.name: scorpion
facts: Scorpions glow under ultraviolet light due to fluorescent chemicals in their exoskeletons.
They can survive for months without food by slowing their metabolism.
Scorpions give birth to live young, which ride on their mother's back until their first molt.
Only about 25 of the 1,500+ scorpion species have venom deadly to humans.

calendar.name: sea cucumber
facts: They breathe through their anus by pumping water in and out of their respiratory tree.
Sea cucumbers can eject their internal organs as a defense mechanism and later regenerate them.
They play a crucial role in ocean ecosystems by recycling nutrients on the seafloor.
Some species can liquefy their bodies to squeeze through small spaces.

calendar.name: sea lion
facts: They are intelligent and can be trained to perform complex tasks.
Sea lions can rotate their hind flippers forward to walk on land.
They are highly social and communicate through barks, growls, and body language.
Sea lions can dive up to 900 feet and hold their breath for 10 minutes.

calendar.name: sea otter
facts: Sea otters have the densest fur of any animal, with up to 1 million hairs per square inch.
They use rocks as tools to crack open shellfish while floating on their backs.
Sea otters hold hands while sleeping to prevent drifting apart.
They play a crucial role in maintaining kelp forest ecosystems by controlling sea urchin populations.

calendar.name: sea turtle
facts: Sea turtles can migrate thousands of miles between feeding and nesting grounds.
They return to the same beach where they were born to lay their eggs.
The temperature of the nest determines the gender of the hatchlings.
Leatherback sea turtles can dive deeper than 1,000 meters (3,280 feet).

calendar.name: seahorse
facts: Seahorses lack stomachs and must eat constantly to survive.
They are poor swimmers, relying on camouflage and slow movements to avoid predators.
They have prehensile tails to grip seagrass and corals, avoiding strong currents.
Seahorses are the only fish where males become pregnant and give birth.

randomAnimals.name: gannet
facts: No facts available.

randomAnimals.name: goose
facts: They fly in V-formation to conserve energy during long migrations.
Geese mate for life and can live over 25 years.
They can fly at altitudes up to 29,000 feet.
Geese have excellent memories and can remember migration routes for life.

randomAnimals.name: impala
facts: Males defend territories during mating season, often engaging in horn clashes.
Impalas have a unique dental arrangement that allows them to chew food efficiently.
They use a behavior called 'pronking,' where they leap stiff-legged to confuse predators.
Impalas are known for their incredible leaping ability, jumping up to 10 feet high and 30 feet far.
